magnesium.positive: Magnesium supports GABA receptor activation and melatonin regulation. A positive response suggests your body benefits from additional magnesium, which is common — most adults are deficient.
magnesium.negative: Magnesium plays a role in GABA receptor activation and melatonin regulation. A negative response may indicate you're already sufficient, or that this form isn't well absorbed. Consider trying a different form (glycinate, threonate, or taurate).

magnesium l-threonate.positive: Magnesium L-threonate is the only form shown to cross the blood-brain barrier effectively, boosting brain magnesium levels. A positive response suggests enhanced cognitive function and neuronal magnesium status.
magnesium l-threonate.negative: Mag threonate specifically targets brain magnesium. A negative response is uncommon — if you're not noticing cognitive benefits, the issue may not be brain magnesium. Try glycinate for sleep or taurate for heart.

collagen.positive: Collagen peptides provide glycine, which supports inhibitory neurotransmission and connective tissue repair. A positive sleep response likely reflects glycine's calming effect on the nervous system.
collagen.negative: Collagen peptides support connective tissue repair. Effects on sleep are indirect — typically through glycine content. A negative response may indicate glycine isn't a limiting factor for you.

vitamin d.positive: Vitamin D regulates circadian rhythm signaling and immune function. A positive response is common — deficiency affects over 40% of adults and supplementation often shows measurable improvements.
vitamin d.negative: Vitamin D regulates circadian rhythm signaling. A negative response may indicate you're already sufficient, or that you're taking it too late in the day. Morning dosing with fat is optimal.

vitamin c.positive: Vitamin C supports immune function, acts as an antioxidant, and aids cortisol regulation. A positive response suggests reduced oxidative stress is benefiting your recovery.
vitamin c.negative: Vitamin C supports immune function and acts as an antioxidant. Sleep effects are typically indirect. A negative response may relate to its mild stimulatory effect — try taking it earlier in the day.

b complex.positive: B vitamins support energy metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis including serotonin and melatonin. A positive response suggests improved methylation and neurotransmitter balance.
b complex.negative: B vitamins support energy metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis. A negative sleep response is common when taken later in the day — B6 and B12 can be stimulating. Try morning dosing.

ashwagandha.positive: Ashwagandha modulates cortisol and HPA axis activity. A positive response likely reflects reduced stress signaling, which is one of the most well-supported effects in clinical research.
ashwagandha.negative: Ashwagandha modulates cortisol and HPA axis activity. A negative response is uncommon but can occur — some people experience thyroid stimulation or mild GI disruption that affects sleep.

omega 3.positive: Omega-3 fatty acids (EPA/DHA) reduce systemic inflammation and support cell membrane fluidity. A positive response often correlates with lower inflammatory markers and improved brain function.
omega 3.negative: Omega-3 fatty acids reduce inflammation and support brain function. A negative response is rare — consider whether the source quality is sufficient or if you're already getting enough from diet.

fish oil.positive: Fish oil provides EPA and DHA, which reduce systemic inflammation and support neuronal membrane health. A positive response suggests your body benefits from additional omega-3 intake.
fish oil.negative: Fish oil provides EPA and DHA for inflammation reduction. A negative response may relate to oxidation of the oil (check freshness), GI disruption, or already sufficient dietary intake.

zinc.positive: Zinc supports immune function, neurotransmitter metabolism, and plays a role in melatonin synthesis from serotonin. A positive response suggests you were likely running low.
zinc.negative: Zinc supports immune function and melatonin synthesis. A negative response may indicate excess zinc, which can disrupt copper balance. Consider testing your levels or reducing dose.

melatonin.positive: Melatonin directly regulates your circadian sleep-wake cycle. A positive response suggests your natural melatonin production may be suppressed (common with screen exposure or irregular schedules).
melatonin.negative: Melatonin regulates the sleep-wake cycle. A negative response may indicate you're taking too high a dose (try 0.3-0.5mg), wrong timing, or that your sleep issue isn't melatonin-related.

curcumin.positive: Curcumin is a potent anti-inflammatory that crosses the blood-brain barrier. A positive response suggests reduced neuroinflammation and improved recovery signaling.
curcumin.negative: Curcumin has potent anti-inflammatory properties but very low bioavailability. A negative response may reflect poor absorption — look for formulations with piperine or liposomal delivery.

elderberry.positive: Elderberry is rich in anthocyanins with strong immune-modulating and antioxidant properties. A positive response suggests reduced low-grade inflammation supporting better recovery.
elderberry.negative: Elderberry supports immune function through anthocyanin antioxidants. A negative response is uncommon — it may relate to its mild immune-stimulating effect. Not recommended during active autoimmune flares.

iodine.positive: Iodine is essential for thyroid hormone (T3/T4) synthesis, which drives metabolic rate, thermogenesis, and sleep–wake regulation. A positive response may reflect correction of suboptimal iodine status and improved thyroid hormone availability.
iodine.negative: Iodine fuels thyroid hormone production. Lack of benefit may indicate adequate baseline intake—or, rarely, sensitivity to increased iodine. If symptoms persist or worsen, consider checking thyroid function and discussing dose with your clinician.
